body: I'll go through the changes and file JIRAs for bugs which are independent enough from IMRU
I've filed REEF-1551, REEF-1552 and REEF-1553 for improvements in non-IMRU parts of the code. Changes to Common are purely logging and I don't think they deserve a separate JIRA.

I also filed REEF-1549 and REEF-1550 to follow up IMRU task host exceptions and WaitingForRegistration. 
@markusweimer @dkm2110 Let us know if it is OK for the merge.
This LGTM, and all the tests pass on my machine. Are there any other tests we should do? @tcNickolas, is this likely to break IMRU fault tolerance?
Any change that touches bridge is likely to break something :-) I would merge REEF-1251 first and then test this change with fault tolerance rather than the other way around

This change could also help with some of the excessive recovery time we suffer from over in REEF-1251, right? This decouples the events from one another and makes the REEF.NET Driver truly event-driven.
`TaskRepresenter` is also an odd place to put this, as the goal is to give access to the state of an Evaluator, not Task. Why not have this in `EvaluatorManager`?
No need to wait for my sign-off. Go ahead and merge.
Thank you, @markusweimer !

Thanks Markus for the confirmation.

I'll merge this in a few hours.

Thanks,
Yunseong
On Thu, Sep 1, 2016 at 10:02 AM Dongjoon Hyun notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Thank you, @markusweimer https://github.com/markusweimer !
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> 
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1109#issuecomment-243947015, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABqtNDU4vxPOEK6impi7n4C6Hh1lfvjvks5qliQhgaJpZM4JvL7M
> .

@markusweimer @tcNickolas For clarification, this PR only decouples the `IDriverStarted`/`IDriverRestarted` events from all other events. So, the `IAllocatedEvaluator` events and others will still run sequentially, and there may not be any decrease in recovery time for REEF-1251. The decoupling of other events will be addressed in later PRs; this is only the first step.

@markusweimer `EvaluatorManager` has some methods to represent it's state of course, but there is no way to access to `EvalautorManager` from driver at runtime. These problematic methods are only used during the test to get the state information of `EvaluatorManager` from driver-side.
I have created a new PR #1112 that supersedes this PR by removing SystemException from all of REEF.NET, so I am closing this PR.

Thank you for review, @yunseong and @markusweimer .
I'll merge this to the master.
@markusweimer I don't expect this change to speed up event handling in fault tolerance code. IMRU driver uses locking extensively, so it handles events sequentially.

How you decide which occurrences of `SystemException` replace with `ReefSystemException` and which ones with `Exception`? Catching `Exception` instead of `SystemException` definitely changes system behavior to catch a much wider class of exceptions

@jwang98052 Could you take a look?
@tcNickolas I decided which replacements to make on a case-by-case basis. We only had one catch(SystemException) in all of Reef, which I changed to catch(Exception) based on my reading of the code.
@zerg-junior done with the fixes - could you please take another look? Thank you!

`catch(SystemException)` looks to catch specific type of exceptions, while `catch(Exception)` catches all of them regardless of type. This is behavior change which should not be done as part of compatibility work.

Same, in `TestTaskExceptions` the check changes from "verify that exception we get is of specific type" to "verify that this is some exception".

Please replace all occurrences of `SystemException` with `ReefRuntimeException` uniformly, so that this change doesn't introduce behavior changes.
Ah, yes, can we make the methods `private`? That way, you have access to them from the tests?

Is this all cosmetic? It isn't clear whether the refactoring to`DriverStatusManager` mentioned above is or is not. If is is not purely cosmetic, can we move all the cosmetic changes into one PR, followed by this one.
I won't be able to do a deep code review soon. Hence, please go ahead without me. There are enough eyeballs on this PR :)
@markusweimer all changes in this PR are cosmetic. There are absolutely no functionality changes - at most, we use more idiomatic java code or different wording in logs

I can see the refactor makes the code reuse between start handler and restart handler. 
Regarding the performance improvement by moving callClrSystemOnStartHandler/callClrSystemOnRestartHandler out of synchronized,  we only have one driver, do we have multi-threads calling start/restart handler at the same time?
I completed a pass.
In the latest commit I have used ReefRuntimeException as suggested in the comments and I have made ReefRuntimeException serializable.
I can't get it. How can I access to `private` methods in driver-side?
Thanks @jwang98052, I left replies on your comments. Could you kindly do another check?
I've done a pass
Should we close this PR? It's not fit for review without .NET side of the code.
Please address comments regarding BindException and ClassHierarchyException exception hierarchy before I can test this PR.
LGTM, will test & merge.

The .NET tests failed twice for me:

```
Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.IMRUCloseTaskTest.TestTaskCloseOnLocalRuntime
Cannot read from log file C:\src\reef\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\REEF_LOCAL_RUNTIMEbd7f449e\reef-BroadcastReduceDriver-20160906175813589\driver\driver.stdout\r\nExpected: True\r\nActual:   False
   at Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.ReefFunctionalTest.ReadLogFile(String logFileName, String subfolder, String testFolder, Int32 retryCount) in C:\src\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Functional\ReefFunctionalTest.cs:line 280
   at Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.IMRUCloseTaskTest.TestTaskCloseOnLocalRuntime() in C:\src\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Functional\IMRU\IMRUCloseTaskTest.cs:line 63
```

This looks like something that could be affected by these re-organizations of code, right?

@markusweimer, thanks for checking! Hmm, I definitely have not changed anything on the .NET side of the project.. Could it be some rebase/merge issue? Anyway, I'll try it again on my PC and let you know soon.

_"Works for me"_ :smiley: - All tests pass on my PC; I ran the test that you mention multiple times in debug and release modes and it had never failed. Can someone else run .NET test on their environment?
.NET tests pass on my machine also as well as in AppVeyor. I've noticed `TestTaskCloseOnLocalRuntime` fail sometimes in AppVeyor previously, so I don't think this PR is to blame.
.Net test passed on my machine.

The test error:Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.IMRUCloseTaskTest.TestTaskCloseOnLocalRuntime
Cannot read from log file C:\src\reef\lang\cs\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\REEF_LOCAL_RUNTIMEbd7f449e\reef-BroadcastReduceDriver-20160906175813589\driver\driver.stdout\r\nExpected: True\r\nActual:   False

fails because the test completed validation before the log file is completely written. If you re-run  the same test again, it would pass.

This error message typically means that evaluator hasn't completed within the period of time for which test waits (2 minutes in this case), so log is not written by the time the test gives up. This requires investigation (because evaluator should shut down by that time) but it's low priority :-(

In general, I am fine with the changes - I think we can merge the PR and refactor it later. I've created a new issue [REEF-1557](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1557) to track the refactoring work.
@tcNickolas I have addressed you review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
I have addressed all comments.
Given my emails on the subject, I feel obligated to take this one. Will merge :)
Ok, so this seems to be a flakiness in our tests more so than a failure induced by this change. I will merge.
I've done another pass. Not sure why AppVeyor build fails, the build passes on my machine.
OK. I will open again when .NET issues are resolved.
I'll merge it, then :)
LGTM
I'll merge
I've done a pass.
I have made another pass addressing all comments.
Looks good and passes tests (the test failing in AppVeyor is known to be flaky). I'll merge
@tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments and pushed the change. Thanks!
I've done a pass

LGTM.
@dkm2110 I remember you had comments about exception handling in FT in REEF-1251. Do you want to take a look?
@tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
I did another pass.

AppVeyor test fail looks like some weird caching issue, the last commit fixed the failure on my machine, so tests pass locally for me. I'll do a couple of minor changes like remove empty tags and fix typos, and will merge
@tcNickolas Rebased with master. Please have a look.
LGTM, will do some minor cleanup and merge

Does this change mean that now all tasks which use group communication have to call `_groupCommClient.WaitingForRegistration();` explicitly in their `Call` method? This seems a bit weird low-level pattern for high-level library use. Is there any way to avoid this?

Yes, explicitly calling groupCommClient.WaitingForRegistration() is my concern as well. But I cannot find a better way. 
User needs to have some understanding for how to use GC in tasks. For example, it is task's responsibility to inject IGroupCommClient, GetBroadcastSender, GetReduceReceiver, etc. We have examples to show to the user for how to use GC. 
We can rename it to Initialize() if that makes user feel batter.
Done with the fixes - thanks for reviewing @tcNickolas !
@tcNickolas I have addressed you review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!

I've done a pass. Two overall comments:
1. We need a unified policy regarding empty lines. Even within this change sometimes you add more empty lines, and sometimes you remove existing ones (in `EvaluatorStatusPOJO` constructor). For example, I'm not sure we need empty lines after opening bracket
2. Same regarding `this.` prefix for instance variables and methods. I'm not convinced we need to start adding `this.` in cases in which instance variable/method is not shadowed by other names. Corresponding Checkstyle [check](http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_coding.html#RequireThis) warns that it is controversial. I've tried running it on our code with `validateOnlyOverlapping=true`, and it found no violations, and Intellij highlights all added `this.` as not needed.

+1 for rename to `Initialize()`, since this is kind of user-facing, a more intuitive name is probably better.

I've done another pass
@tcNickolas addressed review comments.

There are two reproducible test failures (both on my machine and in AppVeyor) - `O.A.R.Tests.Functional.IMRU.IMRUCloseTaskTest.TestTaskCloseOnLocalRuntime` and `O.A.R.Tests.Functional.IMRU.TestFailMapperEvaluatorsOnInit.TestFailedMapperOnLocalRuntime`.
Please investigate

AppVeyor link https://ci.appveyor.com/project/jwang98052/reef/build/88-REEF-1549
@tcNickolas fixed issue that caused the test failure.
LGTM and passes tests. Will merge
What's the status on this?

Regarding `this.`: This is on me :) I've just always written code like that. But with current IDEs, it really is redundant as they highlight object attributes differently from local variables. Still, it makes the code easier to parse & review without a proper IDE, IMHO, e.g. on the code review page on GitHub.

AppVeyor test fails on KMean test with error
Expected number of contexts to close (3) differs from actual number of success indicators (2)

I cannot repro on local test though.

I think when I was looking at Checkstyle we had plenty of places in code in which we don't prefix members with `.this`. I suggest we take `.this` question to the mailing list and vote on a single style, and then configure a check to enforce it.
As for doing code review on Github, I often checkout pull request and view it in proper IDE to simplify the process :-)
KMean failure is transient. On [my run of this change](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/252-REEF-1562/tests) another test fails, also transiently.
LGTM, will merge

So how about we merge this PR and open a low-priority JIRA to state whatever style preferences we want eventually to converge to? Besides `this.`, we can also mention the ordering of `@Parameter`-annotated arguments, and other such things.
LGTM, will test and merge
I'm fine with that. @jwang98052 do you have any more comments?
LGTM
I'll test and merge
LGTM, will merge
@jwang98052 suggested some small changes, and I left some comments on them. If there aren't any other PRs that might be greatly affected by this one, then I'd be very relieved to see this merged.
Thanks, @jsjason! @jwang98052, can you please comment?
LGTM, will test.
AppVeyor build failure is caused by one of our transiently failing tests, but it doesn't get stuck at protoc downloading stage, which is the failure this change is supposed to fix.
Please resolve the conflicts this branch has with current master

Yes! Good find!
--Shravan

I'll merge.

Could we get done with this, either by merging it or rejecting it? There aren't many changes code-wise. The issue @jwang98052 mentioned is not a critical one, and is small enough to be addressed in another issue if it turns out to be a real problem later.
LGTM, will test & merge
Let me package the change for our client to do a testing before merging.
I completed a pass.
I will test and merge.
LGTM

**Did we address all concerns/suggestions that were voiced on mailing list discussion of this change? @markusweimer suggested to obsolete this class as unused, which would make this change unnecessary.**

Yes, I replied to list. See below.

The TimerStage class is used in the following tests on the java side.
PubSubThreadPoolStageTest.java
TimerStageTest.java
LargeMsgTest.java
RemoteManagerTest.java
RemoteTest.java
SmallMessagesTest.java
TransportRaceTest.java
TransportTest.java
though it is not used on the C# side. However, The test code on the C# side appears to be incomplete compared to the java side so I am reticent to delete a class that we may need to provide complete test coverage on the C# side.

The RxTimeStage class class on the other hand is not used on either the java or C# side so I agree we should [Osolete] the RxTimerClass and subsequently delete it both in Java and C#. Java

The difference between TimerStage and RxTimerStage classes is that TimerStage calls EventHandler<PeriodicEvent> instance whereas calls an IStaticObservable for time out events.

**JIRA description mentions System.Net.Dns which needs replacement but is still present here. Do you plan to handle it separately?**

I updated the JIRA as it is better to keep the check in focused on a single change.
